verse_commentaries.commentary: Superscription contains mysterious musical term 'al-hagittith' - possibly 'on the gittith' referring to an instrument or melody. The LXX renders it as 'hyper ton lenon' (concerning the winepress), suggesting early interpretive uncertainty about this technical term.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes liturgical context for cosmic meditation

verse_commentaries.commentary: Double address 'YHWH our Lord' creates hierarchical intimacy - cosmic deity yet 'our' Lord. The inclusio begins here with exact repetition in v.10. Curious verb 'tenah' (covered/set) with 'your splendor' - unusual construction suggesting active divine placement of glory above heavens.
figurative_analysis: covering heavens with splendor - spatial metaphor
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes cosmic frame that brackets human significance meditation
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: yə-hō-**WĀH** 'a-dhō-**NĒY**-nū māh-'a-**DIY**-r shim-**KHĀ** bə-khol-hā-**'Ā**-rets 'a-**SHER** tə-**NĀH** hō-dhə-**KHĀ** ʿal-hash-shā-**MĀ**-yim

verse_commentaries.commentary: Striking paradox of 'infants and sucklings' establishing 'strength' against 'enemies and avengers' - complete reversal of expected power dynamics. The verb 'yissadta' (founded/established) suggests permanent, architectural strength from the weakest sources.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Introduces divine reversal theme - anticipates human insignificance/significance paradox
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: mi-**PIY** ʿō-lə-**LIY**-m  **WƏ**-yō-nə-qiy-m yis-sadh-**TĀ** **ʿŌZ** lə-**MA**-ʿan tsō-rə-**REY**-khā lə-hash-**BIY**-th 'ō-**YĒV** ū-mith-naq-**QĒM**

verse_commentaries.commentary: Intimate anthropomorphism 'work of your fingers' (not hands) suggests delicate artistry. First person 'when I behold' shifts to personal contemplation. Verb 'konanta' (established/set in place) emphasizes divine intentionality in cosmic arrangement.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Sets up cosmic contemplation that leads to human significance questions
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: kiy-'er-**'EH** shā-mey-**KHĀ** ma-ʿa-**SĒH** 'ets-bʿō-**THEY**-khā yā-**RĒ**-aḥ wə-khō-khā-**VIY**-m 'a-**SHER** kō-**NĀ**-nə-tāh

verse_commentaries.commentary: Double rhetorical questions with synonymous yet distinct terms: 'enosh' (frail humanity) and 'ben-adam' (son of earth). Verb pair 'tizkereinu/tifqedeinu' (mindful/visit) moves from memory to active attention - escalating divine involvement.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Central paradox - cosmic insignificance vs divine attention

verse_commentaries.commentary: Crux interpretum: 'me'at me'elohim' - 'little less than God/divine beings/angels'? Royal coronation imagery with 'glory and majesty' - typically divine/royal attributes applied to humanity. The verb 'techaserehu' suggests intentional limitation.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Resolves paradox through divine elevation of humanity
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: wat-ḥas-**SRĒ**-hū mmə-**ʿAT** mē-'e-lō-**HIY**-m wə-khā-**VŌDH** wə-hā-**DHĀR** tə-ʿat-**TRĒ**-hū

verse_commentaries.commentary: Shift from 'fingers' (v.4) to 'hands' (v.7) - cosmic delicacy vs human dominion strength. Royal language 'tamshilehu' (make ruler) and 'under his feet' - ancient Near Eastern royal conquest imagery. Everything placed 'under feet' suggests total subjugation.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Human dominion as answer to cosmic insignificance question

verse_commentaries.commentary: Begins merismus catalog - domestic animals first ('sheep and oxen, all of them') then wild beasts. The phrase 'kulam' (all of them) emphasizes totality within categories. Movement from tame to wild suggests comprehensive scope.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Concrete specification of human dominion claim
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: tsō-**NEH** wa-'a-lā-**FIY**-m kul-**LĀM** wə-**GHAM** ba-ha-**MŌTH** sā-**DHĀY**

verse_commentaries.commentary: Completes three-realm merismus: land animals (v.8), aerial birds, aquatic fish. Curious phrase 'over orḥot yamim' (paths of the seas) - ancient geographical knowledge or poetic imagery? Suggests ordered routes through seemingly chaotic waters.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Cosmic scope of dominion matches cosmic scope of divine majesty
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: tsi-**PŌR** shā-ma-**YIM** ū-dhə-**GHĒY** hay-**YĀM** ʿō-**VĒR** 'or-**ḤŌTH** yam-**MIY**-m

verse_commentaries.commentary: Exact repetition of v.2b creates perfect inclusio - human dignity meditation bracketed by divine majesty. Notable absence of heavens reference here (present in v.2) - focus narrows to earth after cosmic journey. Circular structure suggests resolution.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Human significance comprehended within divine majesty frame

thematic_threads: Vertical movement: heavens (v.2,4) → human between (v.5-7) → earth creatures (v.8-9) → earth focus (v.10)
Anthropomorphic progression: divine fingers (delicate) → divine hands (strong) → human feet (dominion)
Power reversal theme: infants vs enemies (v.3), cosmic insignificance vs royal dignity (v.5-6)
Perfect inclusio creates circular meditation - divine majesty encompasses human significance
interesting_questions: Why does the psalm shift from 'work of Your fingers' (v.4) to 'work of Your hands' (v.7) - what theological distinction does this anthropomorphic contrast serve?
What is the precise meaning of 'elohim' in v.6 - does it refer to God himself, divine beings, or angels, and how does this affect the psalm's anthropology?
How do 'infants and sucklings' establish 'strength' against 'enemies and avengers' in v.3, and how does this relate to the creation theme?
What are the 'paths of the seas' in v.9 - ancient geographical knowledge, mythological imagery, or poetic metaphor for divine order in chaos?
Why does the inclusio in v.10 omit the heavens reference present in v.2 - is this intentional narrowing to earth after the cosmic meditation?
What is the significance of the verb progression 'mindful/visit' (zakar/paqad) in v.5 - do these represent different levels of divine attention?
How does the mysterious 'gittith' in the superscription relate to the psalm's themes, and why did early translators interpret it so differently?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Focus on 'elohim' in v.6, 'gittith' in v.1, anthropomorphic terms (fingers/hands), dominion vocabulary
CONCORDANCE: Track 'name of YHWH' theology, finger/hand distinctions, zakar/paqad verb pairs, inclusio patterns
FIGURATIVE: Royal coronation imagery (v.6-7), merismus structures (v.8-9), anthropomorphic language throughout
COMMENTARY: Interpretive cruxes in v.3 (infants/enemies), v.6 (elohim), v.9 (sea paths), inclusio variation
